blocks.text: Saturday, August 3 – to the Poconos, Rohrbach cottage at Paupack - 149 miles.
Saturday night activities in the cottage...John and Polly Rohrer arrive in their own car.
Monday, August 5 – east into New York State to visit Kathy and John in Greenwich.
Two nights in Greenwich...Kitty in the solarium.
Wednesday, August 7 - north along west bank of Hudson River; cross Bear Mountain Bridge (above); continue north to Lake George; night at Crown Point, N. Y. - = 256 miles.
High above the Hudson River along the Storm King Highway; overcast all day.

blocks.text: Beautiful Lake George; overrun with vacationers at Lake George village; wilderness area as we proceed northward along the lake.
Dinner at old inn in Crown Point.

Thursday, August 8 — into the Adirondacks; cross St. Lawrence River to enter Canada at Ogdensburg; west along St. Lawrence River to Thousand Islands region and Lake Ontario; night at Cobourq, Ontario - 339 miles,.
The Elmo Caesar Saw Fifty Years. For Centuries I Have Stood and Watched The Ceaseless Flow Of Generations Beneath My Branches To And Fro, As Savage, Pioneer and Tourist Know.
View of Lake Champlain in early morning.
Kitty stands along side ancient elm in Keene, N. Y; (see previous trips to the Adirondacks); gasoline here is 63¢ per gallon, most ever paid in U. S.

blocks.text: In the distance, Mt. Marcy at 5,344 feet, highest point in New York State.
Within sight of Mt. Marcy, grave of John Brown, abolitionist who was tried and hanged after his raid on the U.S. arsenal at Harpers Ferry; 1859.
A boy with his fishing rod surveys the waters of Lake Placid, busy vacation site (see other trips).
Bridgegggggg across the SSt. Lawrence River Bridge near Ogdensburg Canada; toll $1.75.
Boats offer a tour of the Thousand Islands; actually there are more than 1,500 islands.

blocks.text: Friday, August 9 — from Cobourg, Ontario to Massey, Ontario, via Toronto, Parry Sound and Sudbury - 366 miles.
We finally run out of heavy traffic north of Toronto and Parry Sound; Canadians with camping equipment in the thousands headed north; few towns here; many lakes and unbroken forests.
Sudbury, a mining city in the Canadian wilderness; International Nickel has large smelters and refineries here; also gold, silver, copper, zinc lead are mined nearby.
Saturday, August 10 — west to Sault Ste Marie; north along east shore of Lake Superior to Mobert, Ontario - 353 miles.
An unusual pontoon-yacht, out of Chicago, at dock at Blind River on the North Channel of Lake Huron.
Roadside pottery shop...gifts for the daughters at home.

The famous locks at Sault Ste Marie between Lake Huron and Lake Superior handle a greater tonnage than by Suez, Panama and Kiel combined; these are the Canadian locks, presently occupied only by sightseeing boats.

blocks.text: The new highway north from Sault Ste Marie along the shore of Lake Superior, mostly through virgin forests well protected from man's depreciation, with outstanding and continuing views of the lake-shore, must be one of the finest drives in N. America.
Although this is a fairly new highway, restaurants are well spaced, food prices are reasonable. Further north motels are in short supply.

The highway turns inland to enter vast Lake Superior Provincial Park.

blocks.text: From the goose memorial the highway winds through virgin forests far as the eye can see.

Sunday, August 11 - around the northern part of Lake Superior in rain and mist all the way to Thunder Bay; reenter the United States near Grand Portage, Minn... night near Grand Marais, Minn – 312 miles.
ROSSPORT MARINA
Rossportsportt, a fishing villlage on Superior's north shore noted for its lake trout.
About to return to the U. S. A. in Minnesota...only a few questions asked...never before have we gone thru customs so quickly.

An early stop at 3:30 in the afternoon near Grand Marais...best motel bargain of the entire trip...only $10 for two...from here it is 350 miles to the opposite shore making Lake Superior probably the largest fresh-water lake in the world.
Typical forested topography of northern Minnesota.

blocks.text: Monday, August 12 - southward along Minnesota's famous North Shore Drive to Duluth; turn eastward through Wisconsin as far as Ashland - 285 miles.
Along the shore of Lake Superior.
Lofty view of Lake Superior from Palisade Head, a volcanic headland reached by a narrow, winding road.
S Split Rock Lighthouse stands 168 feet sheer above the lakeshore.

blocks.text: The Gunflint Trail into one of the truly great remaining wilderness areas in the U. S...land of the early fur traders.
Streams emerge from the forest fastness and cascade into the lake.
$300 million + taconite plant at Silver Bay for the processing of low-grade iron ore.

First locomotive to haul iron ore in Minn., the
"Three Spot", was built in 1887; on display in
Two Harbors.
In Duluth the Aerial Lift Bridge, only one of its kind, connecting the city with Minnesota Point. When a ship's captain takes toots, the bridge rises 120' in less than one minute.

Farm scene in northern Wisconsin, driving east from Superior.
Superior.

blocks.text: A stream flows into Lake Superior along its south shore.
The twenty three Apostolate Islands off Wisconsin's north shore in Lake Superior were probably seen first by French explorers about the middle of the 17th century.
The state highway sign tells the story of Madeline Island, largest of the Apostles,...view of marina, with low-hanging clouds over the lake.
From Bayfield, Wisconsin Gordon and Kitty take the ferry ride to Madeline Island,...stay only about 15 minutes, and return on the same ferry.
Sail boats on the 1½-mile wide channel.

blocks.text: Bayfield is a village apparently favored by artists and craft workers...Kitty purchases a few items as mementos of the visit.
In Bayfield, what appears to be an ancient peanut wagon turns out to be an excellent reproduction.
Motel in Ashland, Wisconsin; for some unknown reason most of the motels are filled; so we pay too much for this one.
A farmer offers specimens of driftwood along the roadside...he trusts you to deposit the correct amount.

blocks.text: Tuesday, August 13 - Ashland, Wis., eastward into Michigan's Upper Peninsula; bridge across Straits of Mackinac; to Poteskey, Mich., for night – 399 miles.
Michigan's Upper Peninsula's Upperkenniganns, its Upper Peninsularnsula, still more than eight hundred percent forest covered; more than four thousand lakes.

One of the great bridges of the world, the five-mile Straits of Mackinac Bridge (toll is only $1.50). Gordon and Kitty last crossed the Straits by ferry when the bridge was still under construction.
Bridge (toll is only $1.50). Gordon and Kitty last crossed the Straits by
Across the bridge into farming country in mainland Michigan.

blocks.text: Almost 500 feet high in places the Sleeping Bear Dunes extend for seven miles along the shore of Lake Michigan... said to be the world's largest shifting sand dune it moves relentlessly inland about two feet a year driven by the wind. A popular spot for young and old who seem to enjoy climbing its steep sides and tumbling down again.
From a bluff, view of large electric power plant south of Ludington.
Best way to see the dunes is in one of the specially built dune scooters.

pages.full_text:
Almost 500 feet high in places the Sleeping Bear Dunes extend for seven miles along the shore of Lake Michigan... said to be the world's largest shifting sand dune it moves relentlessly inland about two feet a year driven by the wind. A popular spot for young and old who seem to enjoy climbing its steep sides and tumbling down again.

From a bluff, view of large electric power plant south of Ludington.

Best way to see the dunes is in one of the specially built dune scooters.

blocks.text: Kristen Mary Connolly is born December 20, 1974 in the hospital in Port Chester, N. Y., weight 7 pounds, six ounces; 20½ inches long.
On the 22nd Gordon and Kitty drive to Port Chester to visit Kathy in the hospital, and to see Kristen for the first time.
From the hospital follow John to home in Greenwich where Gordon and John exchange congratulations and both celebrate with a cigar.

blocks.text: Traditional New Year's Eve party is held at the home of Lou and Flossie Moore on Lampeter Road.
The husbands: (standing) John Rohrer, Bill Robinson, Gordon; (seated) Ed Coe, John Hendricks, Adolph Koehler, Claude Smith, Ame Moore, Jim Farmer and Lou Moore.

The wives; Flossie Moore,
"Brownie" Moore, Betty Smith,
Dottie Hendricks, Ann Cole,
Arline Robinson, Polly Rohrer,
Betty Farmer, Abbie Koehler
and Kitty.

The year 1974 was saddened by the death of Gordon's brother James on December 12, after an extended period of heart deterioration. He was 62. "Uncle Jim" to all the girls, he will missed by all of us.
Much ado...

blocks.text: Another year for Gordon, birthday on August 28. Another year for Gooor Corordon ddonn, bibbitirbittirthirdhiddenday in an An Aauuugustusst 288..
Kitty with the Strawbridges and the Olivers.
The innertubes are tied to the car to be taken to the starting point.

. .David, Louise and the boys come to Hill and Donna Oliver and daughter, Brooke and Dona from Philadelphia...the rest by bicycles from Philadelphia...the rest by down the Conestoga Creek south of (asco)...Gordon drives miles getting them they declare they will try again.
Brooke & Blake.

blocks.text: Thanksgiving, Thanksgiving, 1975 - Gordon and Kitty, Richard and Nancy again are invited to come to Greenwich by John and Kathy ...Thanksgiving dinner includes John's parents, Jack and Mary (Mary shown with Kitty, at left) ...encounter some of worst traffic ever experienced driving through New York city on Thanksgiving day...return to Lancaster Saturday.
"See, I can walk!"...Kristen is now eleven months old....has been walking since ten months, thus setting a record for two generations of the Land-reeth tribe.

blocks.text: John, Kathy and Kristen come to Lancaster on the day after Christmas for three days...Kristen is one year old, a bit awed by all the excitement.

Three evening grosbeaks, part of a flock of 15-16 of these birds, appear at the feeders on December 28. These birds are seen here only during the winter and in early spring, and their appearance is highly irregular.

blocks.text: A covered bridge can still be built...this one on Hunsecker Road replaces the one destroyed during the floods of 1972.

Mark Crede Landreth Kindred is born in San Francisco on February 8, 1976... weight 8 pounds, 12 ounces. Within a few hours after birth he is rushed to Children's Hospital for three hours of major surgery to correct a rare birth defect, a diaphragmatic hernia. Mark remains in the hospital until April 6.
For some reason, during this period, the ring-billed gull also makes an appearance in large numbers.
During February thousands of snow goose congregate in Manor Township fields and on islands in the Susquehanna River.

March 20 & 21 = Grand Rapids
March 20 & 21 = Grand Rapids
March 20 & 21 - Gordon & Kitty to Washington to visit Richard & Nancy...the 20th is first day of Spring, a very mild 78 degrees...return via Fredrick to Lincoln Highway near Gettysburg, and home.
Books everywhere...Richard & Nancy in dining room of their home.
Richard is a teacher at Federal City College.

Back porch gathering...Gordon,
Kitty & Richard.
Kitty & Nancy are shopping on afternoon in Alexandria, Va.
Kitty & Nancy are shopping on afternoon in Alexandria, Va. Strictly for the tourist trade. Gordon buys a box of hand-made cigars. South of Alexandria, along the Potomac River.
Gordon buys a box of hand-made cigars.
Strictly for the tourist trade.
South of Alexandria, along the Potomac River.

A late supper at a neighborhood Greek restaurant on Pennsylvania Avenue.
Gordon & Kitty are fortunate they decide to return home by driving north instead of returning via Baltimore where a storm does extensive damage.
A sharp wind has sprung up as Richard & Nancy say goodbye in front of their home on "E" St.

The warm weather induces Nancy to get out the broom.
A razed building reveals an old Coca Cola sign in Washington.

March 20 & 21 = Grand Rapids
March 20 & 21 = Grand Rapids

March 20 & 21 - Gordon & Kitty to Washington to visit Richard & Nancy...the 20th is first day of Spring, a very mild 78 degrees...return via Fredrick to Lincoln Highway near Gettysburg, and home.

Books everywhere...Richard & Nancy in dining room of their home.

Richard is a teacher at Federal City College.

Back porch gathering...Gordon,
Kitty & Richard.

blocks.text: John, Kathy and Kristen arrive late on Good Fri-day to spend Easter with Gordon and Kitty...stay until following Tuesday. It's 92 degrees, record temperature for 80 yrs.

Kristen in the spotlight
is just short of being sixteen months old.

blocks.text:
RAWLINSVILLE TROLLEY LINE
Operated from 1904 to Jan. 2, 1916.The 6 mi. track began at Martic Forge Junction with the Pequea Trolley Line via Mt. Nebo to Buck.
During camp meeting season hundreds of people rode this trolley through the rugged hills of Southern Lancaster County.
COURTESY OF
TUCQUAN LIONS CLUB
Sign in Rawlinsville recalls years of the trolley lines...this one neither Gordon nor Kitty can remember.
Woodland path...soon foliage will emerge and the world will be beautiful again.
Cindy and Jerry send pictures of Mark after his first trip home from a long struggle for survival in the Children's Hospital in San Francisco.
